Thomas<br><br>The minority threat proposition posits that the size of minority populations<br>is positively associated with levels of formal social control. Recent<br>research in other nations has shown a clear and consistent relationship<br>between the size of subordinate populations and the number of police as well<br>as increased law enforcement spending. This study examined the<br>relationships, in Canada's largest cities, between six indicators of<br>minority populations and both [...] UTP Journals 2015-01-27T14:05:56-05:00 2015-01-27T14:05:56-05:00 University of Toronto Law Journal 65.1 is now available online https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=FEAR-OF-CRIME-RESEARCH;3d582f8e.1501 Now available online...<br><br>University of Toronto Law Journal - Volume 65, Number 1, Winter 2015<br><br><http://bit.ly/utlj571> http://bit.ly/utlj571<br><br>This issue contains:<br><br>The stripping of the trust: A study in legal evolution<br><br>Adam S Hofri-Winogradow<br><br>The law of trusts has spent the last twenty years rapidly shedding many<br>traditional requirements, forms, and restrictions which imposed liability on<br>negligent trustees, protected vulnerable beneficiaries, and prevented the<br>use of trusts to avoid the claims of settlors' and beneficiaries' creditors,<br>including their spouses, their children, and their governments. It<br>considers the perspective from which to assess multiple parts of a complex<br>scheme in a challenge under the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Is<br>the challenge best framed against the scheme as a whole \ufffd\ufffd all or nothing \ufffd\ufffd<br>or against the separate parts? The framing or perspective can have serious<br>implications for the outcome. Based on the 2009 General Social Survey of Canada, this<br>article examines the influence of Aboriginal status on confidence in the<br>police.
